problem:
A student carried out an experiment to determine the concentration of ethanoic acid in vinegar. A 10.0 $\text{cm}^3$ portion of the vinegar was first diluted to exactly 50.0 $\text{cm}^3$. The diluted vinegar solution was titrated against a 0.09 M sodium hydroxide solution in a conical flask. On average, 12.4 $\text{cm}^3$ of the diluted vinegar were required to neutralise 25.0 $\text{cm}^3$ of the NaOH solution. The titration reaction is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$CH_3COOH + NaOH \rightarrow CH_3COONa + H_2O$
(i) Name the piece of apparatus used to measure accurately the 10.0 $\text{cm}^3$ portion of the original vinegar.
answer: pipette / burette

problem:
A student carried out an experiment to determine the concentration of ethanoic acid in vinegar. A 10.0 $\text{cm}^3$ portion of the vinegar was first diluted to exactly 50.0 $\text{cm}^3$. The diluted vinegar solution was titrated against a 0.09 M sodium hydroxide solution in a conical flask. On average, 12.4 $\text{cm}^3$ of the diluted vinegar were required to neutralise 25.0 $\text{cm}^3$ of the NaOH solution. The titration reaction is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$CH_3COOH + NaOH \rightarrow CH_3COONa + H_2O$
(ii) Describe how this piece of apparatus was rinsed before use.
answer: with deionised water / with vinegar

problem:

answer: add (10.0 $\text{cm}^3$ of original) vinegar to (50 $\text{cm}^3$) volumetric flask / to mark with deionised water / (add water to) bring bottom of meniscus to mark

problem:

answer: reference to a factor of 5 / 12.4 ÷ 5 = 2.48 ($\text{cm}^3$)

A student carried out an experiment to purify benzoic acid by recrystallisation, using water as the solvent.
Explain why water is a suitable solvent for carrying out this recrystallisation.
answer:
(benzoic acid has) low solubility in cold water / 
(benzoic acid has) high solubility in hot water

problem:
A student carried out an experiment to purify benzoic acid by recrystallisation, using water as the solvent.
Explain the purpose of the first (hot) filtration.
answer: to remove insoluble impurities

problem:
A student carried out an experiment to purify benzoic acid by recrystallisation, using water as the solvent.
Fluted filter paper in a warm funnel, as shown on the right, is used in the hot filtration. Explain why this arrangement is suitable for hot filtration.
answer:
increased surface area / faster filtration / keeps solution warm / 
avoids benzoic acid coming out of solution / increases yield

problem:
A student carried out an experiment to purify benzoic acid by recrystallisation, using water as the solvent.
Explain why the second filtration is only carried out after a sufficient period of cooling.
answer: to maximise the yield / to allow crystallisation

problem:
A student carried out an experiment to purify benzoic acid by recrystallisation, using water as the solvent.
What observation would the student make that shows that the recrystallised benzoic acid was pure?
answer:
melting point
over a narrow range / sharp / close to correct value

problem:

answer: acidified KMnO4 (solution) // Fehling’s (A and B) // Tollen’s (reagent)

problem:

State the colour change observed for the reagent(s) you have identified.
answer:
pink/purple // blue // colourless
to colourless // to red // to silver

problem:

answer: ethanoic acid

problem:

answer:

$\text{Ag}^{+} \rightarrow \text{Ag}$

problem:
A third student prepared soap in the laboratory. 
Identify the reactants used in the preparation of soap.
answer: fat / lard / oil / triglyceride / e.g. glyceryl tristearate / stearin / tristearin sodium hydroxide / potassium hydroxide

problem:
A third student prepared soap in the laboratory. 
Identify the solvent used in the preparation of soap.
answer: ethanol

problem:
A third student prepared soap in the laboratory. 
Name the co-product formed when soap is prepared in this way. Draw the molecular structure of this co-product, including all atoms and bonds.
answer: propan-1,2,3-triol / glycerol

problem:
The reaction of sodium thiosulfate with hydrochloric acid is described by the following balanced chemical equation: $Na_2S_2O_3 + 2HCl \rightarrow 2NaCl + SO_2 + S + H_2O$
To Investigate the effect of concentration on the rate of this reaction, the experiment was carried out for a number of different concentrations of sodium thiosulfate solution. For each run, a stopwatch was started when 100 $\text{cm}^3$ of $Na_2S_2O_3$ was mixed with 10 $\text{cm}^3$ of 1M HCl. For each run, the reaction was carried out at room temperature, and the time taken for the same mass of sulfur to precipitate was measured. The inverse of that time was taken as a measure of the initial rate of reaction.
The results are shown in the table below.
|Concentration of $Na_2S_2O_3$ (M)| 0.10 | 0.09 | 0.08 | 0.07 | 0.06 | 0.05 | 0.04 | 0.03 |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
|Time (s)| 50 | 56 | 63 | 72 | 84 | 100 | 125 | 168 |
|Rate = $\frac{1}{Time} (s^{-1})$| 0.020 | 0.018 |  |  |  |  |  |  |

(i) Describe a method that could be used to know when the same mass of sulfur had been precipitated in each run.
answer: X placed under flask time (measured until) X not visible /  light-meter (time measured until) same value

(ii) Describe how a 0.10 M solution of $Na_2S_2O_3$ could be used to prepare a 100 $\text{cm}^3$ portion of 0.09 M $Na_2S_2O_3$ solution.
answer: 90 $\text{cm}^3$ of (0.10 M) solution made up (to 100 $\text{cm}^3$) with water

problem: How many (i) protons, (ii) neutrons, are there in a nucleus of helium–3?

problem: State two reasons why real gases deviate from ideal behaviour.
answer: particles have volume / intermolecular forces / collisions not elastic [any two]

problem: The diagram on the right shows two identical flasks, one filled with helium gas and the other filled with oxygen gas.  The flasks are kept at the same temperature and pressure.  There are 2.4 g of gas in the flask of oxygen.  Calculate the mass of helium present.
answer:
reference to masses of 4 and 32 / ratio of 1:8 
$\frac{2.4 \times 4}{32} = 0.3 \, \si{\gram}$

problem: State the standard units of first ionisation energy

problem: State the standard units of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD).

problem: Name three homologous series of organic compounds that contain a carbonyl group.
answer: aldehyde / ketone / carboxylic acid / ester [any three]

during water treatment,

problem:

$\text{H}_2\text{O} + \text{e}^- \rightarrow \frac{1}{2}\text{H}_2 + \text{OH}^-$

problem: Explain the fundamental principle of chromatography.

mobile phase and stationary phase

problem:

Lawrence Bragg

problem:

Dorothy Hodgkin

problem:
In 1885 the Swiss mathematician Johann Balmer wrote a mathematical formula to describe the wavelengths of the visible line spectrum of atomic hydrogen, which is now named after him. However there was no explanation for the existence of these lines until 1913. In 1913 Bohr’s model of the hydrogen atom was shown to be consistent with the Balmer series. Bohr’s model was therefore supported by experimental evidence.
Bohr proposed that the electrons in an atom occupy energy levels. Explain what is meant by the term energy level.
answer: fixed energy / quantised energy / energy in an orbit / energy in a shell of an electron (in an atom)

problem:
In 1885 the Swiss mathematician Johann Balmer wrote a mathematical formula to describe the wavelengths of the visible line spectrum of atomic hydrogen, which is now named after him. However there was no explanation for the existence of these lines until 1913. In 1913 Bohr’s model of the hydrogen atom was shown to be consistent with the Balmer series. Bohr’s model was therefore supported by experimental evidence.
Distinguish between the ground state and the excited states of the electron in a hydrogen atom.
answer:
ground state: lowest energy / n = 1 / stable / in 1s // 
excited states: greater energy / n > 1 / unstable / not in 1s

problem:

Bohr’s model was therefore supported by experimental evidence.

answer: energy is released as a photon / as light / as em radiation / at a specific frequency / $E_m - E_n = h f$

Name the instrument used to examine the line spectrum of an element.
answer: spectrometer / spectroscope

problem:

answer: not possible to (accurately) measure certain pairs of physical properties (e.g. position and momentum/velocity) (3) at the same time

problem:

problem:

The complete combustion of compound A may be described by the following balanced chemical equation: $\ce{CH3(CH2)6CH3(l) + 12O2(g) -> 8CO2(g) + 9H2O(l)}$
The heat of formation of compound A is –250.3 kJ mol^{-1}.  The heats of formation of carbon dioxide and water are –393.5 kJ mol^{-1} and –285.8 kJ mol^{-1} respectively. Calculate the heat of combustion of compound A.
answer: 8(–393.5) [= –3148] (2 [multiplicative factor] + 1 [sign]) + 9(–285.8) [= –2572.2] (2 [multiplicative factor] + 1 [sign]) – (–250.3) [= +250.3] (2 [multiplicative factor] + 1 [sign]) = –5469.9 (kJ mol^{-1})

When 4.0 moles of steam and 1.0 moles of carbon monoxide were mixed together at temperature $T$ in a container of fixed volume $V$, they reacted to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
An equilibrium was established which is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$   $\Delta H = -38.8 kJ \space mol^{-1}$
Explain what is meant by chemical equilibrium.
answer: forward and reverse reactions have equal rates // concentrations are constant

problem:
When 4.0 moles of steam and 1.0 moles of carbon monoxide were mixed together at temperature $T$ in a container of fixed volume $V$, they reacted to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
An equilibrium was established which is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$   $\Delta H = -38.8 kJ \space mol^{-1}$
Write an expression for the equilibrium constant $K_c$ for this reaction.

When 4.0 moles of steam and 1.0 moles of carbon monoxide were mixed together at temperature $T$ in a container of fixed volume $V$, they reacted to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
An equilibrium was established which is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$   $\Delta H = -38.8 kJ \space mol^{-1}$
At equilibrium at temperature $T$, there were 0.8 moles of hydrogen gas in the container. Calculate the value of $K_c$ for the equilibrium at this temperature.
answer:
$\frac{[H_2O]}{V} = \frac{3.2}{V}$ // $\frac{[CO]}{V} = \frac{0.2}{V}$ // $\frac{[CO_2]}{V} = \frac{0.8}{V}$
[accept expressions for concentrations with or without reference to V]
$\frac{0.8 * 0.8}{3.2 * 0.2} = 1$

problem:
When 4.0 moles of steam and 1.0 moles of carbon monoxide were mixed together at temperature $T$ in a container of fixed volume $V$, they reacted to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
An equilibrium was established which is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$   $\Delta H = -38.8 kJ \space mol^{-1}$
If the same reaction had been carried out at the same temperature $T$ in the same container, but with an initial mixture of 2.5 moles of steam and 2.5 moles of carbon monoxide, explain why the value of $K_c$ would not change from the value calculated in (a)(iii) above. Explain why the value of $K_c$ would not change.
answer: no change in temperature / $K_c$ is only affected by temperature

problem:
When 4.0 moles of steam and 1.0 moles of carbon monoxide were mixed together at temperature $T$ in a container of fixed volume $V$, they reacted to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
An equilibrium was established which is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$   $\Delta H = -38.8 kJ \space mol^{-1}$
If the same reaction had been carried out at the same temperature $T$ in the same container, but with an initial mixture of 2.5 moles of steam and 2.5 moles of carbon monoxide, calculate the mass of carbon dioxide present in the container at equilibrium in the case described in (b)(i).
answer:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$.
initially 2.5 2.5 0 0
equilibrium 2.5 - x 2.5 - x x x
[accept expressions for concentrations with or without reference to V]
$\frac{x^2}{(2.5 - x)^2} = 1$
$x = 1.25 \space (moles)$
$M_r = 44$
mass = 55 g

problem:
When 4.0 moles of steam and 1.0 moles of carbon monoxide were mixed together at temperature $T$ in a container of fixed volume $V$, they reacted to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
An equilibrium was established which is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$   $\Delta H = -38.8 kJ \space mol^{-1}$

answer:
no effect (3) 
equal number of moles/molecules (of gas) on both sides

problem:
When 4.0 moles of steam and 1.0 moles of carbon monoxide were mixed together at temperature $T$ in a container of fixed volume $V$, they reacted to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
An equilibrium was established which is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$   $\Delta H = -38.8 kJ \space mol^{-1}$

answer:
reduce temperature (3) 
exothermic reaction favoured / (forward) reaction is exothermic

problem:
When 4.0 moles of steam and 1.0 moles of carbon monoxide were mixed together at temperature $T$ in a container of fixed volume $V$, they reacted to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide.
An equilibrium was established which is described by the following balanced chemical equation:
$H_2O_{(g)} + CO_{(g)} \rightleftharpoons H_{2(g)} + CO_{2(g)}$   $\Delta H = -38.8 kJ \space mol^{-1}$
In an industrial context, a catalyst is usually used to ensure that equilibrium is established as quickly as possible for this reaction.  State the effect of using a catalyst on the value of $K_c$ at temperature T.  Justify your answer.
answer:
no effect (3) 
(rate of) forward and reverse reactions affected equally / only rate affected / 
catalyst only affects time taken to reach equilibrium / $K_c$ is only affected by T

problem:

answer:
(initiation/homolysis): $Cl_2 \rightarrow 2Cl^\bullet$ in the presence of uv/light,
(propagation): $C_2H_6 + Cl^\bullet \rightarrow ^\bullet C_2H_5 + HCl$,
(propagation):$^\bullet C_2H_5 + Cl_2 \rightarrow C_2H_5Cl + Cl^\bullet$,
(termination):e.g., $^\bullet C_2H_5 + Cl^\bullet \rightarrow C_2H_5Cl$

Unlike many other environmental problems, stratospheric ozone depletion has been largely remedied by international agreement about the use of CFCs. The damaging effect of CFCs on the ozone layer was predicted by the Mexican chemist Mario Molina before the 'hole' in the ozone layer was observed.

Iron metal is extracted from its ores by reduction in a blast furnace like that illustrated in the diagram on the right.
(iii) Identify by-product B that is removed at the bottom of the furnace.
answer: slag / CaSiO_3 / CaAl_2O_4

problem:
Carbon monoxide acts as a reducing agent in the blast furnace.
(iv) Write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction of carbon monoxide with iron(III) oxide.
answer: Fe_2O_3 + 3CO \\rightarrow 2Fe + 3CO_2

problem:
Steel is an alloy of iron.
(v) Name the main stages in the manufacture of steel using the electric arc process.
answer: charging, melting, refining, tapping, casting [any three]
